journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering

title-group.article-title: Design flow for the crash box in a vehicle to maximize energy absorption

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Mechanical Engineering, Hanyang University, Seoul, Republic of Korea
2Center of Novel Synthesis of Structural and Mechanical Systems, Hanyang University, Seoul, Republic of Korea
3Pak Business Team, Samsung SDI, Chungcheongnam-do, Republic of Korea
4Research & Development Division, Hyundai-Kia Motors, Gyeonggi-do, Republic of Korea
5Department of Mechanical Engineering, Hanyang University, Gyeonggi-do, Republic of Korea

author-notes.corresp: Gyung-Jin Park, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Hanyang University, 1271 Sa 3-dong, Sangnok-gu, Ansan-Si, Gyeonggi-do 426-791, Republic of Korea. Email: gjpark@hanyang.ac.kr

abstract.p: Vehicle collisions frequently happen at a low speed. Insurance companies and the Research Council for Automobile Repairs both require reduction of repair costs and improvement in occupant safety in a low-speed crash. In order to reduce repair costs, an energy absorbing device such as the crash box is usually installed. The crash box is a thin-walled structure attached between the vehicle bumper structure and the side rail. The determination of the crash box geometry is quite important to absorb the impact energy, since the installation space of the crash box is not very large. In this research, a design procedure to determine the cross-sectional dimensions is proposed to enhance the energy absorption capability of the crash box. The proposed process has two steps. In the first step, the cross-sectional dimensions for the conceptual design are determined in two ways. One is a parameter study using discrete design with an orthogonal array. The cross-sectional dimensions of the crash box are selected among the available cross-sections, such as a circle or a polygon. The cross-sectional dimensions are determined by the analysis of the mean from the discrete design with an orthogonal array. The other is topology optimization, which is performed to determine the cross-section of the crash box to maximize the absorbed strain energy based on the Research Council for Automobile Repairs test conditions. The equivalent static loads method for non linear static response structural optimization is employed to solve the formulated topology optimization problems. The cross sections of the crash box are determined from the results of the conceptual design. In the second step, the detailed design processes are performed by using discrete design with an orthogonal array for the models that are selected in the first step. The detailed shapes of the new crash boxes are determined from the detailed design. The optimization problem for the crash box is formulated considering the geometric constraints of fitting into the given space for the crash box. Three new types of crash box are suggested, with detailed shapes from the proposed design procedure.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Many governments have established a variety of regulations to enhance the safety of drivers and passengers, and these regulations have to be satisfied.1–3 Insurance companies adjust the insurance rates when checking the repair cost of the vehicle and the injuries of the passengers at the crash site. Customers tend to purchase a safer vehicle.4,5 Recently, crashworthiness has received considerable public attention, and research on vehicle crashworthiness is actively being carried out by academics and automotive companies. Advanced numerical algorithms and computer advances make it possible to simulate an automobile crash. But automobile crash optimization is still quite difficult due to high nonlinearity and numerical cost. Impact simulation and analysis need extensive computational resources.

Fang et al.6 compared the response surface method (RSM) and the radial basis function (RBF) method for multiobjective optimization of a vehicle body in a frontal impact. Craig et al.7 used the variable screening technique to reduce the number of full-scale finite element analyses. Forsberg and Nilsson8 and Liao et al.9 investigated optimization problems using the RSM and the Kriging method. In these researches, approximate methods were developed and investigated. Efficient design methods and sampling techniques are used for the advanced construction of the approximation method. However, it is difficult to match the exact performance of the original model accurately to the metamodel. Also, the computational cost is still quite high for large scale problems with many design variables.

There have been many attempts to apply topology optimization to the crashworthiness optimization problem of the vehicle structure. Mayer et al. presented topology optimization to minimize the internal energy.10 Forsberg and Nilsson performed topology optimization, where the target internal energy density is defined as the objective function.11 Patel et al. solved a problem to minimize the difference between the internal energy of the designed structure and the target value of internal energy using the Hybrid Cellular Automaton (HCA) method.12 Pedersen defined the multiobjective function for considering the safety of the passengers and the absorbed energy of the structure.13

Vehicles often collide with other vehicles or obstacles at a low-speed. In this case, the safety of the occupant as well as the reduction of the repair cost is quite important. Research Council for Automobile Repairs (RCAR) is organized to enhance the safety of the passengers and to decrease the repair cost of the vehicles.4 The objectives of RCAR are to evaluate the cost of automobile insurance and to make vehicles safer, less damageable, and more cost effective to repair after an accident happens. In a low-speed crash, damage to the automobile frontal structure frequently occurs. The role of the automobile frontal structure is to obstruct the transmission of impact energy to the vehicle body, and to prevent damages to the vehicle body by absorbing impact energy. To maximize the absorbed energy of the frontal structure, a crash box is installed in the automobile frontal structure. The cross-sectional shape of the crash box considerably affects absorption of the impact energy because only a small space is allowed for the crash box.

Automotive companies register new shapes of the crash box or ideas for crash box design as patents.14–17 It is important to obtain a new design of the crash box while avoiding the patents of other automotive companies. There is a limitation in the design of a new crash box when using only the intuition or know-how of the designers. So, proposing a design procedure for the design of a new crash box is significant. In this research, a design procedure is proposed for a new cross-section design of the crash box to guarantee the safety of the passengers at low-speed and to reduce the repair cost.

The design procedure consists of a conceptual design step and a detailed design step. For the conceptual design of the crash box, discrete design with orthogonal arrays (DDOA) and topology optimization using the equivalent static loads method for non linear static response structural optimization (ESLSO) are employed. DDOA is also utilized for the detailed design step. Although the design of experiments (DOE) using the factorial design provides exact data, it is expensive because all allocations of the experiments are required. Thus, fractional design is generally adopted to save expenses. Fractional design analyses the results by using a part of the factorial cases. There are many methods in fractional design. Fractional design is indirectly used in the response surface method (RSM), in that the response surfaces are derived from information from fractional design. Orthogonal arrays which were introduced by Rao in 1946 can be used for cases of fractional design.18 That is, the results of the cases in the orthogonal arrays are indirectly used to generate the response surfaces. However, the results of the orthogonal arrays are directly used for the fractional cases in DDOA. In general optimization or the RSM, optimum results are found in a continuous space. In many cases, available values exist in a discrete manner. There are some methods for discrete design, such as integer programming, genetic algorithms (GA), simulated annealing and so on, which are mathematically excellent. If the method such as GA is directly utilized for discrete design, a large number of experiments (function calculations) are required and the cost is very high, especially for crashworthiness. If an approximation model is constructed for GA, the cost is inexpensive, but only approximate values are obtained as the solution. DDOA can be exploited at low cost when conventional optimization is very expensive or not possible at all.

The idea of ESLSO was initially proposed for linear dynamic response size and shape optimization by Choi and Park in 2002.19 Equivalent static loads (ESLs) are linear static loads which generate the same displacement field by nonlinear dynamic analysis. The efficiency of ESLSO has been verified by various researchers.20–22 Nonlinear dynamic response size and shape optimizations using ESLSO have been investigated,23 and crashworthiness design using ESLSO has also been researched.24 An overview based on research for ESLSO was published in 2011.25 Topology optimization for a linear dynamic system26,27 and a nonlinear static system28 using ESLSO was studied.

The crash box is designed using the proposed design procedure. Conditions such as the material, the size of the installation space, constraints and so on are determined arbitrarily. The objective function and characteristic function are newly defined for the given problem at each design step. In the conceptual design, the objective is to maximize the absorbed energy of the crash box. For topology optimization, the displacement constraints are considered to prevent damage to neighboring components in the frontal structure. Based on the results of the conceptual design, the initial models for the detailed design are constructed. Detailed design is carried out using DDOA. Then, a new characteristic function is defined as the absorbing strain energy ratio of the crash box. The objective of the detailed design is to maximize the value of the characteristic function. New cross-section designs of the crash box in a low-speed crash are introduced by using the proposed design procedure.

Crash analysis is carried out by LS-DYNA.29 NASTRAN DMAP30 is used for calculating the equivalent static loads (ESLs). NASTRAN31 is utilized for linear static topology optimization. Microsoft visual C++32 is used to interface the commercial systems and the automatic process in ESLSO.

sec.title: Background theory
sec.p: A crash box design problem considers the RCAR test conditions. The new design procedure for the design of the crash box is explained in a section below. In the design procedure, discrete design with orthogonal arrays (DDOA) and topology optimization using ESLSO are employed. In this section, the RCAR test, DDOA and ESLSO for topology optimization are explained.

sec.title: RCAR test
sec.p: The Research Council for Automobile Repairs (RCAR) is an international organization that works towards reducing insurance costs by improving automotive damageability, repairability, safety and security.4 A test to evaluate the crashworthiness performance was established by RCAR. A crash box is inserted between the bumper rail and the side rail to absorb the impact energy in the RCAR test conditions. Figure 1 shows the RCAR test conditions at a low-speed (15 km/h). The test is a 40% overlap frontal impact into a rigid barrier angled at 10°.

caption.p: RCAR test conditions.

sec.p: Figure 2 presents the schematic view for the RCAR test of the frontal structure. The bumper rail primarily absorbs the impact energy at the frontal impact. After the impact, the residual energy which is not absorbed by the bumper rail is transmitted to the crash box and the side rail. The crash box must totally absorb the residual energy to reduce the repair cost, because the side rail is connected to the vehicle body. As illustrated in Figure 2, there are interior parts such as the radiator and head lamps in the frontal structure. After the frontal impact, the bumper rail and the crash box only should be replaced, because the purpose of the RCAR test is to reduce the repair cost. When deformation of the crash box is increased while absorbing the impact energy, damage occurs between the bumper rail and parts such as the radiator and head lamps. The crash box must be deformed so as to prevent damage to these interior parts. Based on RCAR test conditions, the roles of the crash box are to totally absorb the impact energy and to prevent damage to the interior parts.

caption.p: RCAR test conditions with the frontal structure of the vehicle.

sec.title: DDOA
sec.p: DDOA is employed both for conceptual design and for detailed design. DDOA is one of the fractional design methods in the field of the design of experiments (DOE). The method has been developed for problems where mathematical optimization is not possible.18 There are some terminologies in DOE as follows. A characteristic function is the response of the system. Factors are the sources which affect the characteristic function value and are equivalent to the design variables in design. The values that the factors can have are the levels.
The Taguchi way to express the orthogonal arrays is as follows33

where N is the number of rows in an orthogonal array, n is the number of factors, si is the number of levels, and ki is the number of factors with si levels. For example, L9(34) is the orthogonal array which has 9 rows and 4 factors with 3 levels. Table 1 shows the L9(34) orthogonal array, and ηi is a characteristic function value of the ith experiment. In factorial design, 34=81 experiments are needed. In the orthogonal array in Table 1, only 9 experiments are required. Various orthogonal arrays have been defined based on the numbers of factors and levels.33

caption.p: L9(34) orthogonal array.

sec.p: The characteristic function value is generated for each experiment in the orthogonal array. The purpose of the experiment is to maximize or to minimize the characteristic function. The results are made from a few experiments because the orthogonal array is a fractional design and the results may not be the best solution. Since a better solution can be found in the levels which do not exist in the orthogonal array, the analysis of means (ANOM) is carried out using the characteristic function values (ηi) of the fractional cases in an orthogonal array. A one-way table is employed for ANOM. Table 2 shows the one-way table of L9(34) as an example. From the one-way table, the effect of the levels for each factor can be calculated. mpq is the mean when factor p has the qth level.

caption.p: An example of the one-way table for an orthogonal array L9(34).

sec.p: When the goal of the experiment is to minimize the characteristic function, the levels with the smallest mean in each row of the one-way table shown in Table 2 are selected. In the first row in Table 2, if mA1 is the smallest among mA1, mA2 and mA3, the optimum level of factor A is the first level and it is called A1. In the same manner, if the means are the smallest in the rows when factor B has level 1, factor C has level 2, and factor D has level 3, then the optimum level from the one-way table is A1B1C2D3. The optimum level may or may not match with a row in the orthogonal array. A confirmation experiment with the optimum level is performed. If the value of a confirmation experiment is smaller than all the characteristic function values in the orthogonal array, the above optimum levels are the final solution. Otherwise, the final solution for DDOA is the row which has the smallest characteristic function value in the orthogonal array. The final solution from the orthogonal array and ANOM may not be the best solution for the problem. But DDOA is cheaper than factorial design, and a good solution can be obtained based on engineering sense.

sec.title: ESLSO for topology optimization
sec.p: ESLSO is adopted for nonlinear dynamic response topology optimization for the conceptual design of the crash box. Equivalent Static Loads (ESLs) are static loads which generate the same displacement field in static analysis as the displacement field at each time step of crash analysis (nonlinear dynamic analysis). The equilibrium equation with nonlinear dynamic behavior is

where M is the mass matrix, C is the damping matrix, K is the stiffness matrix,

The overall process of the ESLSO is illustrated in Figure 3. The process is repeated until the convergence criterion is terminated. The repetition process is called a ‘cycle’. The steps of the nonlinear dynamic response topology optimization process are as follows:

caption.p: Flowchart of topology optimization considering nonlinear dynamic characteristics using ESLs.

Step 4. Solve the linear static response topology optimization problem with ESLs:

sec.p: αi is the transformation variables of the ith corresponding design variables bi. The total number of design variables is the same as that of the transformation variables. A separation parameter ε1 is a certain value between bmin and 1. If the value of a design variable is larger than a separation parameter, the corresponding transformation variable has a value of 1. If not, the corresponding transformation variable is regarded as 0. All the design variables are replaced by 0 or 1 using the transformation variables.

list-item.p: Step 6. Update the results. The transformation variables of value 1 are selected and the corresponding elements remain in the finite element model. The element corresponding to the transformation variables having a value 0 is removed in the finite element model. The updated finite element model is utilized for nonlinear dynamic analysis in Step 2 and calculating ESLs in Step 3 in the next cycle.
Step 7. When k=0, go to Step 2 for the next cycle. Otherwise, if

sec.p:
then terminate the process. Convergence parameter ε2 is an arbitrary value between 0 or 1 because αi is a value of 0 (non-existent element) or 1 (existent element). ε3 is a certain percentage. The number of transformation variables which are changed more than ε2 between adjacent cycles, is counted. If the counted number is smaller than

)
, the process is regarded as converging. In an extreme case, ε3 can be zero.
ESLSO is able to perform nonlinear dynamic response topology optimization using well established nonlinear dynamic analysis (crash analysis) and linear static topology optimization.

sec.title: Design procedure
sec.p: The crash box is installed in a small space between the bumper rail and the side rail. Because the side rail is connected to the vehicle body, if the side rail is deformed, the safety of the passengers in the vehicle cannot be guaranteed and the repair cost can increase. So, the crash box should absorb the impact energy to the maximum. Since the installation space of the crash box is fixed, only the cross-section shape can be changed. The installation space varies depending on the type of the vehicle. If an existing crash box is used, the energy absorption capability of the crash box may not be maintained. A design procedure which can determine a new cross-section design of the crash box is proposed whenever the design conditions are changed. The proposed design procedure enables a crash box with a new cross-section to decrease the repair cost in a low-speed crash by maximizing the absorption energy.
Figure 4 illustrates the design procedure. The design procedure has a two step sequence which consists of conceptual design and detailed design as follows:

caption.p: The design process for determination of the cross-section.

list-item.p: Step 1. Define the design conditions such as the installation space for the crash box, materials, and the allowable deformation.
Step 2. Perform conceptual design. There are two procedures for conceptual design: DDOA and topology optimization using ESLSO.

The factors, levels and the characteristic function are determined for DDOA. The factors are identified by the cross-section shape, the thickness of the crash box and the material used. Various candidates of each factor are defined as the levels of the corresponding factor. If sources increasing the absorbed impact energy are perceived, the sources are selected as the factors. DDOA determines the best solution among the given factors, but an entirely new shape may not be obtained. The characteristic function is defined as the strain energy or the specific energy absorption (SEA) to maximize the absorbed energy of the crash box. SEA is the absorbed energy per unit mass. An appropriate orthogonal array is selected according to the numbers of the factors and the levels, and the fractional design of DDOA is carried out. The results of this step may not be directly used for the final design; therefore, a new shape should be redrawn based on the results of this step.
Step 2-2. Perform topology optimization using ESLSO.

Topology optimization is carried out separately from Step 2-1. The design domain is defined according to the installation space of the crash box. The objective function is defined as maximization of the strain energy of the crash box. In the design of the crash box, the strain energy at the final time step is employed as the objective function because the energy absorption at the end time is important. A volume (or mass) constraint is defined to satisfy the specific volume in the defined design domain. In addition, the displacement constraints should be considered to prevent damages of the interior parts, such as the radiator and head lamps, in the frontal structure. Topology optimization can give a completely new type of cross-section. However, the results of topology optimization cannot be utilized directly for the detailed design in the next step because manufacturing of the results of topology optimization can be difficult or impossible. The designer should redraw the cross-section of the crash box based on the results of topology optimization.
Step 3. Determine the initial design for a detailed design based on the results of conceptual design.

The crash box with a new cross-section shape can be individually obtained from DDOA and topology optimization using ESLSO. The initial design can be defined by the results of Step 2-1, Step 2-2 or a combination of Steps 2-1 and 2-2. In this process, the capability of the designer is crucial because different initial designs can be obtained.
Step 4. Perform a detailed design using DDOA.

Detailed design is performed based on the results of Step 3 using DDOA. The factors and levels for the detailed design should be defined. The factors are the detailed geometries which are not considered in conceptual design, and the levels are the values that the factors can have. The characteristic function may or may not be the same as the one defined in Step 2-1. Examples of factors and the characteristic function for the detailed design are explained in a later section.

The objective function (characteristic function) and design variables (factors and levels) are defined based on the performance of the crash box in a low-speed crash. The design is performed using the proposed design procedure, and new cross-section designs of the crash box are obtained.

sec.title: Conceptual design
sec.p: Conceptual design is carried out using the proposed design procedure. For the conceptual design of the crash box, DDOA and topology optimization using ESLSO are performed. The design formulation and the finite element model are different for each conceptual design.

sec.title: Conceptual design using DDOA
sec.p: The finite element model and design conditions are defined for the conceptual design using DDOA. Figure 5 illustrates the finite element model of the crash box for the simplified RCAR test. A simplified finite element model is used instead of a full scale model. As shown in Figure 2, the frontal structure crashes into a fixed rigid wall in a real situation. In the analysis condition, the rigid wall moves towards the crash box with an initial velocity of 15 km/h. The rigid wall is half the weight of the entire vehicle because there are two crash boxes in the frontal structure of the vehicle, as shown in Figure 2. All the degrees of freedom at the bottom of the crash box are fixed because the bottom is connected to the side rail.

caption.p: The finite element model for DDOA of the crash box.

sec.p: As illustrated in Figures 1 and 2, the crash box is deformed after a rigid wall angled at 10° collides with the bumper rail. In a real crash situation, the angle between the rigid wall and the front of the crash box can be varied. Because there is no bumper rail in the simplified finite element model, it is difficult to simulate the same crash situation in Figure 2. The loading condition is defined by a condition that a rigid wall angled by 0° moves towards the crash box. The degrees of freedom at the top of the crash box connected to the bumper rail are set free in the x translational direction, and the other degrees of freedom are fixed. The analysis and loading conditions are defined in Figure 5. Contact exists between the rigid wall and the upside part of the crash box. During the crash, the side of the crash box comes in contact with the rigid wall, and the sides of the crash box may also contact each other. Contact surfaces are defined based on these contact conditions. The static coefficient of friction is 0.2, and the dynamic coefficient of friction is 0.15.

The length of the crash box is 125 mm because the length of the allowable installation space of the crash box is assumed to be 125 mm. The finite element is a shell element with 4 nodes, and the material used is steel. If the finite element model is changed, the analysis and design conditions can be changed. LS-DYNA is utilized for the crash analysis.
The characteristic function for DDOA is the specific energy absorption (SEA), which is the absorbed energy per unit mass as follows

where W is the total absorbed energy and m is the mass of the crash box. The model with the largest characteristic function value is the optimum model. Based on the characteristics of the structure and the situation of the crash, the other crashworthiness parameters such as the strain energy and crash force efficiency can be utilized as the characteristic function as well. The factors for the DDOA are shown in Figure 6, and the levels are shown in Table 3. The factors and levels are selected by the sponsor’s request. The number of factors is six and they are: section shape, length, tapered angles, material and thickness. The candidates of the section shape are the circle, square, hexagon, octagon and dodecagon. According to existing patents, when tapered angles are made at the top or bottom side of the crash box, the energy absorption capability improves.14–16 So, the tapered angles at the top and bottom side are adopted as factors, as shown in Figure 6.

caption.p: The factors of DDOA for conceptual design.
Factors and levels for conceptual design.

sec.p: As shown in Table 3, the problem has one factor with five levels and five factors with three levels. Based on the numbers of factors and levels, L18(51×36 is chosen for the conceptual design. If the numbers of the factors and levels are different, another orthogonal array may be chosen. L18 orthogonal array is for one factor with two levels and seven factors with three levels. L18(21×37 orthogonal array is modified for this problem. Factor AB has five levels as the mixed factor with two factors, as shown in Table 3. The octagon is added as the dummy level for factor AB because it is expected that the octagon will have large energy absorption capability. Owing to five factors with three levels, one factor is missing for L18(51×36. The missed factor is empty in the orthogonal array. The results of the experiments are shown in Table 4.

caption.p: Results of L18 (51×36) for conceptual design.

sec.p: The values of the characteristic function are shown in Table 4. The levels with the largest SEA in L18 are AB2C2D1E3F1G2 at the 17th experiment. The analysis of mean (ANOM) from the orthogonal array are performed and the one-way table is shown in Table 5. The levels from the one-way table are AB2C2D1E3F3G1, and SEA is 15.39 kJ/kg. Because the SEA in the 17th row of the orthogonal array (16.06 kJ/kg) is larger than that of the one-way table results (15.39 kJ/kg), the final solution from DDOA are the ones in the 17th row (AB2C2D1E3F1G2). The crash box has an octagonal sectional shape, thickness of 0.8 mm, length of 125 mm, tapered angle of 0° at the top side, and tapered angle of 3° at the bottom side. If other factors or a different characteristic function are used, the optimum results can be changed.

caption.p: One-way table for conceptual design.

sec.title: Conceptual design using topology optimization
sec.p: The second conceptual design of the crash box is topology optimization using ESLSO, as illustrated in Figure 3. Figure 7 shows the finite element model and loading conditions for topology optimization. The analysis conditions are defined by the designers. The conditions for topology optimization may or may not be the same as the analysis conditions for DDOA in the section above. In this example, a real crash situation in Figures 1 and 2 is utilized for topology optimization. As shown in Figure 7, two loading conditions with a rigid wall angled at 10 degrees and a non-angled rigid wall are defined for topology optimization.

caption.p: The finite element model and loading conditions for topology optimization. (a) Loading condition no. 1, (b) loading condition no. 2.

sec.p: The formulation for linear static response topology optimization in ESLSO is as follows

where bi is the ith design variable, q means the final time step in crash analysis and vi is the volume of the ith finite element. V is the given limit volume of the design domain, and 40% volume fraction is used for V. The number of design variables is 6804. Because the absorbed energy of the crash box is continually increased during the crash, the crash box may absorb the impact energy to the maximum when the impact is finished. Therefore, the objective function is to maximize the strain energy at the final time step in the event of a crash. The role of the crash box is also to protect the interior parts, such as the radiator and head lamps, from damage. The allowable displacement dallowable is to prevent damage to the interior parts. The extrusion condition in the x-direction is considered for manufacturing. If the extrusion condition is not utilized, connectivity between the side rail and the bumper rail can be broken. Two kinds of topology optimization problems are performed with different displacement constraints. Displacement constraints are defined as the distance between the interior parts and the bumper rail, as illustrated in Figure 2. These constraints differ between types of vehicles. The allowable displacement of the first problem, which is called ‘Problem A’, is 90 mm, and that of the second problem, which is called ‘Problem B’, is 40 mm. LS-DYNA for crash analysis, NASTRAN for optimization and NASTRAN DMAP for calculating the ESLs are employed. The finite element model and the contact conditions for crash analysis are the same as those defined for the conceptual design using DDOA above.

Figure 8 presents the topology optimization results of the crash box. The material of the elements having a black color should remain, and the elements with a white color should be removed in the finite element model. The optimization process for Problem A converges in five cycles and Problem B is finished in six cycles. As illustrated in Figure 8, a partition such as Part A exists in the middle of the crash box. Because Part A and the outside panels are deformed together during the crash, the absorbed energy of the crash box is increased. There is a pillar in Problem B. Because the displacement constraint can be more easily violated in Problem B, the stiffness of a crash box is maintained as a pillar.

caption.p: Topology optimization results. (a) Problem A, (b) Problem B.

sec.p: After topology optimization is finished, the designer should redraw the design for the detailed design or for manufacturing. As shown in Figure 8, the results of topology optimization cannot be directly used for the detailed design in the next step. The designers should draw the cross-section shape with the results of topology optimization. The crash box with a new cross-section is defined for the detailed design by using the results of conceptual design.

sec.title: Detailed design
sec.p: The initial designs for the detailed design are made based on the results of the conceptual design. In this step, crash boxes with new cross-section shapes are obtained.

sec.title: Determination of the initial designs for the detailed design
sec.p: The initial designs for the detailed design are determined by the results of the conceptual design using DDOA and topology optimization. Figure 9(a) shows the finite element model made from the results of DDOA. Figure 9(b) and (c) are the new cross-section shapes made from the results of topology optimization in Figure 8. The proposed cross-section shapes from the topology optimization results can be different, depending on the designers. So, in this step, the experience, intuition and capability of the designer is very important. This is a shortcoming of this step.

caption.p: Initial shapes for the detailed design. (a) Model from the orthogonal arrays, (b) model from topology optimization Problem A, (c) model from topology optimization Problem B, (d) combined model.

sec.p: It is noted that Figure 9(a) has an octagonal sectional shape, while Figure 9(b) and (c) have a partition from Part A or a pillar from Part B in Figure 8. A new initial design can be proposed by combining the two results. A new model is established, as illustrated in Figure 9(d), as a combination of the two results of DDOA and topology optimization using ESLSO. It has a partition in an octagonal cross-section. The capability of the designer is important because different models can be established. As shown in Tables 4 and 5, the thickness of the finite element model from DDOA in the conceptual design step is 0.8 mm. Because Figure 9(b), (c) and (d) are obtained from the results of topology optimization, information about the thicknesses for three models does not exist. So the mass for the models in Figure 9(b), (c) and (d) is defined by regulating the thickness based on the mass of the model in Figure 9(a). In other words, the four models in Figure 9 have the same mass, even if the thicknesses of the models are different.

Crash analysis is conducted for the models in Figure 9(a) and (d) to evaluate the performance of the crash box when the model from DDOA in Figure 9(a) includes a partition. The analysis condition is shown in Figure 5. The strain energy of the model in Figure 9(a) is 4.42 kJ, and the strain energy of the model with a partition in Figure 9(d) is 4.91 kJ. Thus, three finite element models in Figure 9(b), (c) and (d) are selected as the initial designs for the detailed design. The welding parts are constructed by using panels for manufacturing, as shown at Part C in Figure 9(b) and (d). Figure 9(c) does not have welding parts because this model cannot be manufactured with panels.

sec.title: Detailed design of the crash box
sec.p: The finite element model for the detailed design is established as illustrated in Figure 10. The model consists of the crash box and a side rail. The front side is connected to the bumper rail while the rear side is connected to the side rail. Because the bumper rail is omitted in the finite element model, the loading condition is defined as a non-angled rigid wall that moves toward the crash box with an initial velocity of 15 km/h, as shown in Figure 10. Design conditions for the detailed design are as follows: length is 80 mm; width is 65 mm; height at the front side is 85 mm; height at the rear side is 100 mm. These design conditions can be changed according to the type of the vehicle. The design domain is only the crash box. The allowable displacement of the crash box is 60 mm at the crash, and the allowable buckling load is 80 kN. If the buckling load of the crash box is larger than the allowable buckling load, the side rail is deformed and the safety of the passengers may not be guaranteed. The type of finite elements, material and the contact conditions are the same as those defined for the conceptual design in the earlier section.

caption.p: The finite element model and loading conditions for the detailed design.

sec.p: Figure 11 presents the schematic view of the F–d (force–displacement) curve of an arbitrary crash box at the crash. Fmax is the maximum buckling load and Fmin is the minimum buckling load. The area under the F–d curve indicatess the absorbed energy of the crash box. The solid line is a real F–d curve and the dotted line is an ideal F–d curve with an allowable buckling load of 80 kN and an allowable displacement of 60 mm. The area under the ideal F–d curve is the maximum. So the maximum absorbed strain energy of crash box, W, is 4.80 kJ, as in equation (9). Suppose the absorbed energy, E, of the arbitrary crash box and the side rail is 5.64 kJ as in equation (10)
where m is the mass of the crash box and the side rail and v is the initial velocity.

caption.p: The schematic view of the F–d curve.

sec.p: As illustrated in Figure 2, the total residual energy should be absorbed by the crash box to prevent damage to the side rail after the bumper rail absorbs the impact energy to the maximum. When the bumper rail is not considered in the analysis conditions in Figure 10, the crash box cannot totally absorb the impact energy, as shown in equations (9) and (10). Therefore, the purpose of the crash box is to absorb the strain energy to the maximum, and the area under the F–d curve should be maximized to maximize the absorbed energy of the crash box. The characteristic function in equation (11) is defined for the detailed design

As illustrated in Figure 12, the displacement df corresponding to the allowable buckling load 80 kN is identified, and the strain energy is calculated at the time step corresponding to the displacement df. The characteristic function is the energy absorption capability of the ideal strain energy when the magnitude of displacement is df. If the maximum buckling load of the crash box is larger than 80 kN or the displacement df is larger than 60 mm, the characteristic function value is regarded as 0. If the design is performed for the finite element model with the bumper rail, the other characteristic function can be used. The characteristic function for the detailed design can be defined according to the finite element model, the allowable displacement and the allowable buckling load. Then the optimum results can also be different.

caption.p: F–d curve for calculation of the characteristic function

sec.p: The first model for the detailed design is the finite element model based on the topology optimization results in Figure 9(b). This model is called ‘Model 1’. The factors and levels are defined for the detailed design using DDOA of Model 1. The factors are sizes of the crash box, thickness, and the number of notches. Notches decrease the difference between the Fmax and Fmin in Figure 11.14,16 The fluctuation of the F–d curve is reduced and the absorbed energy is increased when the difference is reduced. The factors for Model 1 are illustrated in Figure 13, and the factors and levels are shown in Table 6. The levels, except for the number of notches, are normalized with respect to the first level.

caption.p: The factors of DDOA for the detailed design of Model 1.
Factors and levels for the detailed design of Model 1.

sec.p: The number of the factors and levels are similar to those for the conceptual design using DDOA above. The numbers of inside and outside notches are defined as factor AB and have five levels. The two notches at the inside and outside are determined for the dummy level. The factors for each thickness and size have three levels. For DDOA of Model 1, L18 orthogonal array which is used for the conceptual design is employed. If the factors and levels are changed, another orthogonal array can be selected.

Table 7 shows the orthogonal array and the characteristic function values of Model 1. Because the maximum buckling load of the 3rd, 9th, and 10th experiment is larger than the allowable buckling load of 80 kN, the characteristic function values are regarded as 0%. Because the goal of DDOA is to find the largest characteristic function value, the 16th experiment is the optimum level in an orthogonal array. When ANOM is carried out, the levels from the one-way table in Table 8 are AB5C2D2E1F1G2H2. The confirmation experiment with these levels is performed, and the characteristic function value is 70.87%. Because this value is smaller than that of the optimum levels in the orthogonal array, the final solution of DDOA is AB1C1D3E2F3G1H2 from the 16th experiment in an orthogonal array. Figure 14 illustrates the F–d curve when the crash analysis is performed with the final results with the analysis condition in Figure 10. The displacement corresponding to the buckling load 80 kN is 49.08 mm, and the mass of the crash box is 283.2 g. Figure 15 shows the shapes of Model 1 before and after the crash. Figure 15(a) shows the side rail and crash box on the x–y plane. The finite element model on the left side illustrates the deformation shapes of Model 1 at point A in Figure 14. The side rail is omitted for clarity of the deformed shape in Figure 15(b) and (c).

caption.p: Results of an orthogonal array for Model 1.
One-way table for Model 1.
F–d curve of the optimum result of Model 1.
The deformation shapes of Model 1 before and after the crash. (a) Side view, (b) isometric view, (c) front view.

sec.p: The second model is the model based on the results of topology optimization Problem B in Figure 9(c), and this model is called ‘Model 2’. The factors and levels for Model 2 are shown in Figure 16 and Table 9. The factors and levels are similar to those of Model 1. Table 10 shows the orthogonal array and the characteristic function values of Model 2. The characteristic function value is the largest in the 4th experiment, and 77.84%. The levels from the one-way table in Table 11 are AB4C3D3E3F2G3H3. When the confirmation experiment is performed with the levels AB4C3 D3E3F2G3H3, the characteristic function value is 80.63%. Because the value from ANOM is larger than that from an orthogonal array, the optimum levels of Model 2 are AB4C3D3E3F2G3H3. The number of notches inside is three and the number of notches outside is two. The mass of Model 2 is 176.7 g. Displacement, df, is 47.745 mm, and Figure 17 illustrates the F–d curve of Model 2. The maximum buckling load, Fmax, is very close to the allowable buckling load of 80 kN. So, the energy absorption capability is quite large. Figure 18 shows the shapes of Model 2 before and after the crash.

caption.p: The factors of DDOA for the detailed design of Model 2.
Factors and levels for the detailed design of Model 2.
Results of an orthogonal array for Model 2.
One-way table for Model 2.
F–d curve of the optimum result of Model 2.
The deformation shapes of Model 2 before and after the crash. (a) Side view, (b) isometric view, (c) front view.

sec.p: The third model is the finite element model using results of both DDOA and topology optimization in Figure 9(d). This model is called ‘Model 3’. The factors and levels for Model 3 are shown in Figure 19 and Table 12. The factors of Model 3 are similar to those of Models 1 and 2. Table 13 is the characteristic function values of Model 3. The maximum energy absorption capability is 80.98% at the 7th experiment. When the confirmation experiment is carried out with the results of the one-way table in Table 14, the characteristic function value is 79.91%. Thus, the optimum levels of Model 3 are AB3C1D2E1F3G2H3. There are two notches at both the inside and outside of the crash box. Figure 20 is the F–d curve when the crash analysis is performed with the optimum levels of Model 3, and Figure 21 illustrates the deformed shapes of Model 3 at point A in Figure 20. The displacement, df, is 45.27 mm, and the mass of the crash box is 256.2 g.

caption.p: The factors of DDOA for the detailed design of Model 3.
Factors and levels for the detailed design of Model 3.
Results of an orthogonal array for Model 3.
One-way table for Model 3.
F–d curve of the optimum result of Model 3.
The deformation shapes of Model 3 before and after the crash. (a) Side view, (b) isometric view, (c) front view.

sec.p: Table 15 shows the energy absorption capability and the mass of the three designs. The characteristic function values of Models 2 and 3 are large. The mass of Model 2 is much smaller than that of Models 1 and 3. Therefore, Model 2 is the best out of the three designs. However, manufacturing Model 2 using panels is impossible and Model 2 should be made by an extrusion process. The material cost is inexpensive due to the low mass, but the cost for manufacturing is increased.

caption.p: The results of three crash boxes.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: When designing the structure of a vehicle, crashworthiness of the frontal structure should be considered to minimize passenger injuries, to reduce the impact energy transferred to the vehicle body and to reduce the repair cost of the vehicle. The frontal structure consists of a bumper rail and a side rail, and the crash box is inserted in order to satisfy the crashworthiness conditions. In a low-speed crash, damage to the vehicle and passenger injuries should be reduced as the crash box absorbs the impact energy to the maximum.

The nonlinearities of crashworthiness are quite large. If a new crash box is proposed by modifying the existing crash box, it cannot be guaranteed that the performance of the existing crash box will be maintained in the new crash box. The crash box should satisfy various specifications and has limited installation space. The shape of the crash box affects the performance of the crash box. To modify the existing crash box is not easy because the design conditions for the crash box are different whenever the type, shape or size of the vehicle are changed. Therefore, a design procedure is proposed to design a new cross-section of the crash box. There are two steps in the proposed procedure: conceptual design using DDOA and topology optimization with ESLSO, and detailed design using DDOA. The design or analysis conditions, of which the structure should satisfy, may be different at each step. Also, the design variables (or factors and levels) and the objective function (or the characteristic function) can be different for each step. Conceptual design and detailed design using DDOA is useful when the factors for a characteristic function are known. Conceptual design using topology optimization with ESLSO provides an entirely new cross-section shape of the crash box. The cross-section of the crash box can also be obtained from the combination of the results of DDOA and topology optimization using ESLSO.

New cross-sections are generated using the proposed design procedure. Based on the results of DDOA and topology optimization in the conceptual design step, three kinds of cross-sections are suggested. Detailed design using DDOA is performed for each design. Factors in the detailed design are more varied than in conceptual design using DDOA. Energy absorption capability is enhanced by adopting the notches on the outside panels for each model. The three crash boxes with new cross-sectional dimensions are obtained and these have high energy absorption capability and light mass. If the defined design conditions (such as characteristic function, factors, levels, objective function, constraints, size of installation space, allowable displacement, allowable buckling load, materials and so on) are changed, the results of the design can be changed. So, an accurate definition of the design conditions for the crash box is very important.

There are many crashworthiness optimization problems. The proposed design procedure is only applied to the crash box. Further research is needed to apply it to other crashworthiness optimization problems. Various crashworthiness parameters have been utilized in the crash analysis. For crashworthiness optimization of the crash box, the parameters of strain energy, maximum buckling load and displacement are used as the responses. If different characteristics of the structures or different crash conditions are considered, the responses considered in the current study can be changed. Additional research is needed. The purpose of the design is defined as a low-speed crash, and the purpose is satisfied. Because the performance requirements of the crash box in a high speed crash are different, the design procedure should be expanded and modified for a high-speed crash.

ack.p: The authors thank Mrs MiSun Park for her English correction of the manuscript.
